Instead of computing $P(2)$, simply find $k = Q(r) - 1$, where $r$ is the unique real root of the derivative of $Q$. Does there exist an irrational number $\alpha>k$ such that $\left\lfloor\alpha^{n}\right\rfloor \equiv 0 \quad(\bmod 2017)$ for all integers $n \geq k$ ?

$ Q(x) = x^2 + 2x + 3 $

Then $ Q'(x) = 2x + 2 $

Set $ Q'(x) = 0 $:

So the unique real root $ r = -1 $
